text: Today's front page: the stories San Francisco is talking about this morning. https://t.co/sgK7iFvtYo https://t.co/fXGEA6A4qa

name: sfchronicle
text: California environmentalists opposed to development in semi-urbanized areas are increasingly fighting projects with a new weapon ‚Äî the dangers of wildfire. https://t.co/sZ6dxL6KKJ

name: sfchronicle
text: After years of plunging homicide numbers, the Bay Area is witnessing a dramatic spike.  https://t.co/n2ZtMWMeiy

name: sfchronicle
text: Across the world, more than 40 million people now have been infected with the coronavirus, as of Monday‚Äôs tracking by Johns Hopkins University, a tally that experts say is surely an undercount. More than 1.1 million people have died in the pandemic.  https://t.co/LiOKVHsuh4 https://t.co/TYhUm6OXO1

text: Proposition 22 is the most expensive ballot initiative in modern California history. https://t.co/aoL7WfjIHz

name: sfchronicle
text: ‚ÄúWe need transparency, meaning the public needs to be able to access the information about the gun dealers most responsible for putting crime guns on the street,‚Äù said Christian Heyne, Brady‚Äôs vice president of policy. https://t.co/w7m3qbKCk4

name: sfchronicle
text: In a call with campaign staff. President Trump laid into Dr. Anthony Fauci, saying ‚ÄúPeople are tired of hearing from Fauci and all these idiots,‚Äù CNN, which listened in on the call, reported Monday.   https://t.co/i22EtjAbSX https://t.co/Lu6etuE7ir

name: sfchronicle
text: The Supreme Court will review two cases involving Trump administration border policy: one about a policy that makes asylum-seekers wait in Mexico for U.S. court hearings and a second about the administration's use of money to fund the border wall.  https://t.co/4jDrqHQPtH https://t.co/2badjuFI0O

name: sfchronicle
text:
The massive Glass Fire burned down the three-Michelin-starred Restaurant at Meadowood.

Here‚Äôs what some former employees have to say about its highly-disciplined ‚Äî and allegedly toxic ‚Äî work environment.

Listen üéß:
https://t.co/Byyait0NoE

name: sfchronicle
text:
‚ÄúIt was an incredible place, and in losing it, you lose decades of history,‚Äù said S.F. chef Traci Des Jardins.

For some former employees, however, the eulogizing of the Restaurant at Meadowood reminded them of an intense, allegedly toxic work environment.
https://t.co/S3Nep9Q7y7

name: sfchronicle

name: sfchronicle
text:
Why is ‚Äúengaged time‚Äù such a big deal? 

Answers to this and other questions about Prop. 22: https://t.co/BZaismLCr3

name: sfchronicle
text: Prop. 22 guarantees drivers earn at least 120% of local minimum wage plus 30 cents a mile, both only for engaged time. At a minimum wage of $15 an hour, that means $18 an hour in wages. https://t.co/9UrsrAgt9o

name: sfchronicle
text:
In the latest indication that he‚Äôs not willing to stick to sports, Warriors point guard Stephen Curry is launching a book club called Underrated. The club concentrates on authors and stories often overlooked by the mainstream public. 
https://t.co/52onj683pi

name: sfchronicle
text: Gov. Gavin Newsom, unveiling distribution priorities for an eventually approved coronavirus vaccine, said Monday that people should not anticipate general-public distribution until next year.  https://t.co/swRaSjJNUX https://t.co/ooX9VXnZsk

name: sfchronicle
text:
Today, Oct. 19th, is the last day to register to vote in California. 

(You can still register until election day, but your vote will be conditional and your eligibility subject to confirmation.)

For more election-related FAQs:

https://t.co/otvTKBlaBK

name: sfchronicle
text: Across California, Latinos account for 61% of cases and nearly 49% of deaths, even though they represent less than 39% of residents. https://t.co/BnYPIBMAcL

name: sfchronicle
text:
Gov. Newsom says California will review any FDA-approved coronavirus vaccine before distributing it. A scientific review committee includes S.F.'s health officer and epidemiology experts from UC Berkeley, Stanford University and Kaiser Permanente.
https://t.co/sjsDlzr2qU

name: sfchronicle
text:
California‚Äôs greenhouse gas emissions rose slightly in 2018 ‚Äî a worrying sign for a state committed to slashing climate-warming emissions in the coming decades. Data is generally reported with a two-year lag, so 2018 represents the most recent numbers.
https://t.co/EG7LY14MWp
